chain_of_thought_reasoning: To find the average blood albumin level for female patients diagnosed with SLE and with PLT greater than 400, I'll start by querying the necessary tables: Patient and Laboratory. First, I need to identify female patients (SEX = 'F') who have a diagnosis (Diagnosis = 'SLE'). I will join the Patient table with the Laboratory table on their shared ID to access the laboratory results. Then, I will filter for PLT values greater than 400. Finally, I'll calculate the average albumin level from the Laboratory table using AVG(ALB) and ensure to filter out any null values in the relevant columns to get accurate results.
SQL: SELECT AVG(T2.ALB) FROM Patient T1 JOIN Laboratory T2 ON T1.ID = T2.ID WHERE T1.SEX = 'F' AND T1.Diagnosis = 'SLE' AND T2.PLT > 400 AND T2.ALB IS NOT NULL;
SELECT AVG(T2.ALB) FROM Patient T1 JOIN Laboratory T2 ON T1.ID = T2.ID WHERE T1.SEX = 'F' AND T1.Diagnosis = 'SLE' AND T2.PLT > 400 AND T2.ALB IS NOT NULL;

sql_generation.Question: What is the average blood albumin level for female patients with a PLT greater than 400 who have been diagnosed with SLE?
sql_generation.Evidence: average blood albumin level refers to AVG(ALB); female refers to SEX = 'F'; PLT greater than 400 refers to PLT > 400; 'SLE' refers to diagnosis
sql_generation.pred_sql: SELECT AVG(T2.ALB) FROM Patient T1 JOIN Laboratory T2 ON T1.ID = T2.ID WHERE T1.SEX = 'F' AND T1.Diagnosis = 'SLE' AND T2.PLT > 400 AND T2.ALB IS NOT NULL;
sql_generation.gold_sql: SELECT AVG(T2.ALB) FROM Patient AS T1 INNER JOIN Laboratory AS T2 ON T1.ID = T2.ID WHERE T2.PLT > 400 AND T1.Diagnosis = 'SLE' AND T1.SEX = 'F'
